string-array.name: sunTzuQuotes
string-array.item: Politics means the thing which causes the people to be in harmony with there ruler so they will follow him in disregard of their lives and without fear of any danger.
Doctrine consists of gradation of rank among officers, regulation of supply routes and provision of military materials to an army.
All warfare is based on deception. Prepare against the enemy when he is secure at all points. Attack him where he is unprepared.
To subdue the enemy without fighting is the supreme excellence.
Politics means the thing which causes the people to be in harmony with there ruler so they will follow him in disregard of their lives and without fear of any danger.
Doctrine consists of gradation of rank among officers, regulation of supply routes and provision of military materials to an army.
All warfare is based on deception. Prepare against the enemy when he is secure at all points. Attack him where he is unprepared.
Speedy victory is the main object in war.
When your strength is exhausted and your treasure spent, other chieftains will spring up to take advantage of your crisis to act.
Bring war material with you from home, but forage on the enemy. Thus the army will have food enough for its needs.
Mix captured chariots with your own. Treat prisoners of war well. This is called "winning the battle and becoming stronger".
In war let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns.
To subdue the enemy without fighting is the supreme excellence.

The highest form of generalship is to balk the enemy plans; the next best is to prevent the junction of his forces; the next in order is to attack their army in the field; and the worst policy of all is to besiege walled cities.
Interference from an ignorant sovereign will bring misfortune on his army.
If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles.
Invincibility depends on ones self, but the enemies vulnerability depends on him.
Defend your self when you cannot defeat the enemy, and attack the enemy when you can.
The skillful fighter puts himself into a position which makes defeat impossible. The victorious strategist only seeks battle after the victory has been won.
The consummate leader cultivates their policies, and strictly adhere to the law and regulations.
The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of organisation.
Use ordinary forces to engage and extraordinary forces to win.
A skilled commander seeks victory from the situation and does not demand it from his subordinates, He selects suitable men and exploits the situation.
Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will arrive exhausted.
The spot where we intend to fight must not be made known; for then the enemy will have to prepare against attack in great many places.
In war, the way is to avoid what is strong and to strike at what is weak.
If I concentrate forces while he divides, I can use my entire force to attack a fraction of his.
Avoid the enemy when his spirit is keen and attack him when it is sluggish.
If one orders his men to make forced marches it is probable the commander will be captured.
You should not encamp on grounds hard to approach. Unite with your allies on ground intersected with highways.
There are some grounds which should not be contested.
5 Fatal Qualities of a Commander: Recklessness, Cowardliness, Quick-Tempered, Delicate Sense of Honour and Compassionate.
Do not assume the enemy will come but rather rely on ones readiness to meet him.
Position yourself on the high ground with the sun at your back.
If officers are short-tempered they are exhausted.
If officers first treat men violently and later fear them it shows supreme lack of intelligence.
If troops are punished before their loyalty is secured they will become disobedient.
If soldiers are strong and the officers are weak an army is insubordinate. If the soldiers are valiant and the officers are ineffective the result is collapse.
A general should treat his soldiers like his own beloved sons and they will follow him until death. If he is unable to control them they can be compared to spoiled children and they are useless.
Attack the enemy where he has taken no precautions.
Throw your soldiers into positions whence there is no escape,and they will prefer death to flight. If they will face death, there is nothing they may not achieve.
It is the business of a general to be quiet and thus ensure secrecy; upright and just, and thus maintain order.
At first exhibit the shyness of a maiden, until the enemy gives you an opening; afterwards emulate the rapidity of a running hare, and it will be too late for the enemy to oppose you.
If you cannot succeed do not employ troops, if you are not in danger do not fight a war.
What enables the wise sovereign and the good general to strike and conquer, and achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men, is foreknowledge.
Spy operations are essential in war; upon them the army relies to make its avery move.
